Introduction:
Plasmid pTY1 (Figure 1a) contained the lacI coding DNA sequence (CDS) and the lactose operator (lacO), together regulating the transcription of a bicistronic mRNA encoding the tetracycline resistance gene (tetA) and Enhanced Yellow Fluorescent Protein (YFP). TetA confers a measurable change in fitness connected with the sensor output. YFP provided a facile means to characterize the plasmid during construction and to evaluate and sort the library using flow cytometry and FACS. We used pTY1 for the barcode-sequencing based measurements of dose-response curves for every sensor in the library.
Plasmid pVER (Figure 1b) contained a similar system in which a lacI and lacO regulate the transcription of only YFP. We used pVER to verify the dose-response curves of select sensors using flow cytometry.
The sequences for all primers used in plasmid assemblies are listed in the Reagents section of this protocol.
The full sequences for the assembled pTY1 and pVER plasmids are listed in the Anticipated Results section of this protocol.

  • Procedure
  • Library Plasmid
  • The Library Plasmid (pTY1, Figure 1a) contains the p15A origin of replication and the kanamycin resistance gene for plasmid maintenance in E. coli. Plasmid pTY1 is constructed from plasmid pAN1818 with the following steps:
  • Remove the tetracycline repressor (tetR) of pAN1818 by PCR amplification (Flash Phusion 2x Master Mix, Thermo Scientific, cat. #F548L) of pAN1818 with primers DT.001 and DT.002
  • Circularize the resulting PCR product using the Gibson method3.
  • Verify the removal with Sanger sequencing.
  • Insert the T7 terminator (TT7) into plasmid pAN1818(-tetR) downstream of the lacI CDS and araC terminator (TaraC) by PCR amplification of plasmid pAN1818(-tetR) with primers DT.003 and DT.004.
  • Circularize the resulting PCR product using the Gibson method.
  • Verify the insertion using Sanger sequencing.
  • Replaced the YFP CDS of pAN1818 with the Sensor Output Sequence, comprising the tacI promoter (PtacI)4, riboJ insulator5, and codon optimized CDSs for tetA and YFP.
  • a. Amplify Sensor Output Sequence as needed by PCR using primers DT.026 and DT.027.
  • b. Inserted the Sensor Output Sequence into pAN1818( tetR+TT7) by amplifying pAN1818(-tetR+TT7) with
  • primers DT.024 and DT.025.
  • c. Assemble the plasmid backbone and Sensor Output Sequence using Gibson assembly.
  • 8. Sequence verified the entire plasmid using Sanger sequencing.
  • Sensor Library Construction
  • The sensor library is constructed by splitting the lacI CDS into an N-terminal half and a C-terminal half. Error-prone PCR of each half is used to introduce genetic diversity, and then each unique sequence is attached to a lineage tracking barcode. Plasmid encoded versions of both sub-libraries are established (an N-terminal library, pNTL, Figure 2, and a C-terminal library, pCTL, Figure 3). These two sub-libraries are then assembled to generate full lacI CDSs and to combine the two halves of the lineage tracking barcode as described below. They are then cloned into plasmid pTY1 (Figure 4).
  • N-Terminal Library
  • The plasmid containing the N-terminal library, pNTL (Figure 2), contains the N-terminal half of the lacI CDS (lacI-N) and a randomized nucleotide sequence that forms half of the dual lineage tracking barcode. Plasmid pNTL is constructed from three linear DNA amplicons (Figure 2a-c). The first amplicon contains the lacI-N CDS library (Figure 2a), which is constructed by amplifying the N-terminal half of the lacI CDS (coding for amino acids M1-A186) from pTY1 using the GeneMorph II Random Mutagenesis Kit (Agilent, cat. #200550) with primers DT.010 and DT.011. The second amplicon (Figure 2b) contained the T7 terminator (TT7), which is amplified from pTY1 using primers DT.007 and DT.008, and then re-amplified with primers DT.007 and DT.009. The third amplicon included the pNTL backbone (Figure 2c), comprising the pMB1 origin of replication (pMB1) and ampicillin resistance gene (AmpR), which are amplified together from plasmid pUC19 (NEB, cat #N3041S) with primers DT.005 and DT.006.
  • During pUC19 backbone amplification, primer DT.005 incorporates the lineage tracking barcodes consisting of 27 randomized nucleotides interspersed with constant A/T bases to limit restriction site formation. Primer DT.005 should be ordered with hand-mixed bases, with ‘N’ representing equal ratios of A, T, G, and C.
  • N-Terminal Barcode: 5’-TNNTNNNANNTNNNANNTNNNANNTNNNANNTNNNANNA-3'
  • The following steps are used to construct the N-terminal library, pNTL:
  • Use assembly PCR with primers DT.007 and DT.011 to combine the lacI-N library amplicon and T7 terminator amplicon.
  • Digest the resulting amplicon with restriction enzymes Fast Digest ApaI and XmaI (Thermo Scientific, cat. #FD1414 and New England Biolabs, NEB, cat. #R0180S, respectively, Figure 2d).
  • Digest the backbone amplicon (Figure 2c) with restriction enzymes ApaI and XmaI and treated with Calf Intestinal Phosphatase (CIP, NEB #M0525L) to prevent auto-ligation (Figure 2e).
  • Purify both fragments with agarose gel extraction using QIAquick Gel Extraction Kit (Qiagen, cat #28115).
  • Ligate both fragments together using T4 DNA ligase (Thermo Scientific, EL0011) to form the final sub-library plasmid pNTL (Figure 2f).
  • Desalted the ligation product using QIAquick PCR Purification Kit (Qiagen, cat. #28106).
  • Transform the desalted product into One Shot TOP10 Electrocomp E. coli (Invitrogen, cat. #C404050).
  • Recover with SOC media at 37 °C while shaking for 1 hour.
  • C-Terminal Library
  • The plasmid containing the C-terminal library, pCTL (Figure 3) contains the C-terminal half of the lacI coding sequence (lacI-C) and a randomized nucleotide sequence that forms the second half of the dual lineage tracking barcode. Plasmid pCTL is constructed from three linear DNA amplicons. The first amplicon contains the araC terminator (TaraC Figure 3a), which is amplified from pTY1 using primers DT.014 and DT.015. The second amplicon contains the lacI-C CDS library (Figure 3b), which is constructed by amplifying the C-terminal half of lacI CDS (coding for amino acids L189-Q360) from pTY1 using the GeneMorph II Random Mutagenesis Kit with primers DT.016 and DT.017. The third amplicon includes the pCTL backbone (Figure 3c), comprising the pMB1 origin of replication (pMB1) and ampicillin resistance gene (AmpR), which are amplified together from plasmid pUC19 with primers DT.012 and DT.013.
  • During pUC19 backbone amplification, primer DT.012 incorporates lineage tracking barcodes consisting of 27 randomized nucleotides interspersed with constant A/T bases to limit restriction site formation. Primer DT.012 should be ordered with hand-mixed bases, with ‘N’ representing equal ratios of A, T, G, and C.

  • The following steps are used to construct the C-terminal library, pCTL:
  • Used assembly PCR with primers DT.014 and DT.017 to combine the lacI-C library amplicon and araC terminator amplicon.
  • Digest the resulting amplicon with restriction enzymes ApaI and XmaI (Figure 3d).
  • Digest the backbone amplicon with restriction enzymes ApaI and XmaI and treat with CIP to prevent auto-ligation (Figure 3e).
  • Purify both fragments with agarose gel extraction.
  • Ligated both fragments together using T4 DNA ligase to form the final sub-library plasmid pCTL (Figure 3f).
  • Desalted the ligation product using QIAquick PCR Purification Kit.
  • Transformed the desalted product into OneShot TOP10 Electrocomp E. coli.
  • Immediately recover with SOC media at 37 °C while shaking for one hour.
  • Library Assembly
  • Plasmids pNTL, pCTL, and pTY1 are starting points to assemble full length lacI CDS and co-localize lineage tracking barcodes (Figure 4). The following steps are used for this assembly:
  • Amplify the lacI-C and lacI-N libraries from plasmids pCTL and pNTL, respectively, by PCR amplification with primers DT.018 and DT.019.
  • Digest the lacI-C library amplicon with restriction enzymes ApaI and DpnI and treated with CIP (Figure 4a).
  • Digest the lacI-N library amplicon with restriction enzymes ApaI and DpnI (Figure 4b).
  • Purify the digested products of both amplicons with agarose gel extraction.
  • Ligate the two together using T4 DNA ligase to assemble the sensor library with full length sensor CDSs (Figure 4c).
  • Purify the ligation product with agarose gel extraction.
  • Amplify the ligated product by PCR with primers DT.018 and DT.019 and again purify with agarose gel extraction.
  • Digest the extracted product with restriction enzymes FseI (NEB, cat. #R0588S) and again purify with agarose gel extraction.
  • Circularize the linear product by ligation using T4 DNA ligase to co-localize barcodes from NTL and CTL (Figure 4d).
  • Linearize the circular product by digestion with restriction enzymes AscI and NheI (Thermo Scientific, cat. #FD1894 and #FD0974, respectively, Figure 4e).
  • Purify the final linear product using agarose gel extraction.
  • Digest purified pTY1 (Figure 4f) with restriction enzymes AscI and NheI then treate with CIP to prevent auto-ligation (Figure 4g).
  • Purify the linear product with agarose gel extraction.
  • Insert the linearized lacI CDS library with corresponding barcode sequences into the pTY1 backbone using T4 DNA ligase with a 3-fold molar excess of pTY1 backbone, resulting in assembly of the library in the plasmid pTY1 (Figure 4h).
  • Desalt the ligation product and then electroporated into MG1655Δlac as described below.
  • Preparation of E. coli Library
  • Prepare electro-competent MG1655Δlac by diluting overnight culture 1000-fold into 500 mL of LB media (BD Biosciences, cat. #244620).
  • Incubated the culture at 37 °C for 3.5 hours in a 2 L baffled Erlenmeyer flask to a final optical density at 600 nm (OD600) of approximately 0.8.
  • Chill the culture in ice slurry for 20 minutes.
  • Centrifuge the culture at 3500 g for 10 minutes.
  • Decant supernatant media, and then resuspended the cell pellet in 500 mL of 10 % glycerol.
  • Centrifuge the solution at 3500 g for 10 minutes.
  • Decant the supernatant glycerol solution.
  • Repeated the glycerol wash one additional time (two washes total)
  • Resuspended the cell pellet with residual 10 % glycerol.
  • Transform the plasmid-encoded sensor library (see above) into the freshly prepared electro-competent MG1655Δlac.
  • Immediately recovered with SOC media at 37 °C while shaking for one hour.
  • Dilute the library in LB media supplemented with glucose (2 g/L, Gibco, cat. #A2494001) and kanamycin (50 µg/mL) to a final volume of 500 mL.
  • Divide the library into 1 mL aliquots and store them in 20 % glycerol at -80 °C (1:1 dilution with 40 % glycerol).
  • Verification Plasmid
  • The Verification Plasmid, pVER (Figure 1b), is used to verify the dose-response curves of sensors identified during the landscape measurements as design targets or as sensors of general interest. Individual sensors are chemically synthesized and inserted into pVER for verification of dose-response curves using flow cytometry. Plasmid pVER contains the same p15A origin of replication and kanamycin resistance gene as pTY1. Additionally, plasmid pVER contains a sensor output sequence similar to the pTY1 plasmid, comprising the PtacI promoter, lacO operator sequence, and riboJ insulator driving the expression of a YFP CDS. The YFP CDS in pVER is from pAN1818.
  • To construct pVER, replace the symL operator in pAN1818 with the lacO operator sequence using PCR with primers DT.022 and DT.023, and then circularize the resulting PCR product with the Gibson method and sequence verify the change with Sanger sequencing, resulting in pAN1818-lacO (Figure 5a).
  • Each synthesized sensor CDS is inserted into the pVER plasmid to give pVER-X, with ‘X’ representing the sensor identification number, using the following steps:
  • Amplify synthesized sensor CDSs by PCR using the Twist universal adapter sequences DT.020 and DT.021.
  • Digest synthesized CDSs with restriction enzymes AscI and XhoI and then desalt the PCR product.
  • Prepare pAN1818-lacO backbone DNA by digesting purified plasmid with restriction enzymes AscI and XhoI, treating with CIP, and purifying the desired product with agarose gel extraction (Figure 5b).
  • Ligate the sensor CDS into the backbone using T4 DNA ligase.
  • Desalted the ligation product and electroporated into MG1655Δlac.
  • Verified sensor sequences by Sanger sequencing.

The sensor library is constructed by splitting the lacI CDS into an N-terminal half and a C-terminal half. description: Here, we describe protocols for assembly of two different plasmids used for the measurement of the genotype-phenotype landscape of the LacI protein in E. coli: a Library Plasmid (pTY1, Figure 1a) used for the landscape measurement of the sensor library, and a Verification Plasmid (pVER, Figure 1b) used to verify the function of approximately 120 sensors from the library chosen to test the accuracy of the landscape measurement and to demonstrate the range of sensor function. We also describe the protocol used for the creation of the LacI sensor library in E. coli.
